TEXT: The applicant , a citizen of GPE born in DATE , resides in PERSON in GPE .
A.
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant entered GPE as a seasonal worker in DATE . In DATE he married PERSON , a citizen of GPE who arrived in GPE in DATE and is currently working as head of department in a supermarket . As a result of the marriage , the applicant was granted an DATE residence permit . Their son PERSON was born in DATE .
At a date not specified in the application the applicant suffered an accident while at work . Part of his left arm was amputated , and he now draws an invalidity pension .

On DATE ORG ( Bezirksgericht ) sentenced the applicant to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , a fine of MONEY ( CHF ) and CARDINAL years’ expulsion from GPE , inter alia , on account of professional insurance fraud and contravening LAW ( GPE ) , in particular gun - running firearms to GPE . The expulsion from GPE was suspended on probation for a period of DATE . No appeal was filed against this judgment .

By letter dated DATE ORG ) of GPE informed the applicant that his DATE residence permit ( GPE ) would only provisionally be prolonged until DATE , as the judgment of ORG had not yet entered into legal force . On DATE ORG decided no longer to prolong the applicant ’s residence permit in view of his criminal conviction . The applicant ’s appeal against this decision was dismissed by ORG ( NORP ) of the GPE of GPE on DATE .
On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) fined the applicant MONEY for having contravened LAW ( Betäubungsmittelgesetz ) while in prison .
On DATE the applicant was released from prison on probation .

The applicant filed an appeal against the decision of DATE which was upheld , on DATE , by ORG ( Verwaltungsgericht ) of the GPE of LOC . The ORG noted in particular that the Government of the GPE of LOC had overlooked that the applicant ’s wife had obtained as from DATE a right to domicile in GPE ( Niederlassungsbewilligung ) .
On DATE the applicant ’s wife and son were granted the right to domicile in GPE .
The applicant ’s renewed appeals against the refusal to prolong his residence permit were dismissed by the Government of the GPE of GPE on DATE and by ORG of the GPE of GPE on DATE .

The applicant filed an administrative law appeal ( PERSON ) which ORG ( PERSON ) dismissed on DATE . The ORG relied in particular on LAW of LAW ( Bundesgesetz über PERSON ) according to which a foreigner will lose his right to a prolongation of a residence permit if he breaches public order . The ORG then weighed the public interest in not renewing the applicant ’s residence permit in view of his criminal conviction with his interest in remaining with his family in GPE .

The ORG considered in particular that the applicant had shown considerable “ criminal energy ” in that he had regularly committed offences of the same type while in GPE . He had furthermore maintained regular contacts with his home country to which he had occasionally returned during his stay in GPE .

The ORG furthermore found that the applicant ’s wife would undoubtedly suffer in her professional activities if she followed the applicant to GPE , though this did not suffice as a reason to prolong his residence permit . Their son was of an adaptable age and could be expected to follow his parents . The issue furthermore arose whether the separation could still be regarded as being disproportionate since the wife had stated during the proceedings that she would in any event remain in GPE with their son , even if the applicant left GPE .
As a result , the ORG did not find it disproportionate that the applicant ’s residence permit had not been renewed .

On DATE ORG ( ORG für ORG ) informed the applicant that he had to leave GPE by DATE . By decision of the same date the ORG prohibited the applicant from entering GPE for a period of DATE , i.e. until DATE .
B. Relevant domestic law and practice
Section CARDINAL of LAW ( Bundesgesetz über PERSON ) states :

“ CARDINAL . As a rule the authority shall at the outset only grant a residence permit to the alien , even if the latter envisages permanently to stay in the country . The ORG shall determine in each case DATE as from when it shall grant the right to domicile .

CARDINAL . If this date has already been determined , or if the alien is entitled to the right to domicile , the spouse shall be entitled to a residence permit , or to have it prolonged , as long as the spouses live together . After a regular and uninterrupted residence of DATE the spouse shall also be entitled to the right to domicile . Unmarried children DATE shall be included in the right to domicile if they live together with their parents . These rights expire if the entitled person has breached public order . ”
